page.title: 01THE AYLMERTON AREA
page.content: The area contains the highest point in Norfolk - 102 metres - at{Roman Camp. From this point, the land dips very gently southwards but steeply northwards, and is part of the{ {Cromer-Holt Ridge}- a glacial terminal moraine. The steep slope composed of sands and gravels is wooded, while the lighter sandy soils on the gentle slope are used for arable farming. Sand and gravel deposits are quarried in Britons Lane, and concrete products are made - the only manufacturing in the area. The east of the area is thickly wooded on the Felbrigg Estate, and{Felbrigg Hall,}now run by the{ {National Trust,}attracts many people. Caravan sites near Roman Camp confirm the importance of tourism. The main settlement is{Aylmerton,}a quiet unspoilt rural community.
